datafield.subfield: A Ringed Dwarf LINER 1 Galaxy Hosting an Intermediate-mass Black Hole with Large-scale Rotation-like ${\rm{H}}\alpha $ Emission

We report the discovery of a 20 kpc sized ${\rm{H}}\alpha $ emission in SDSS J083803.68+540642.0, a ringed dwarf galaxy (${M}_{V}=-17.89$ mag) hosting an accreting intermediate-mass black hole at z = 0.02957. Analysis of the Hubble Space Telescope images indicates that it is an early-type galaxy with a featureless low-surface brightness disk (${\mu }_{0}=20.39$ mag arcsec(−)(2) in the V band) and a prominent, relatively red bulge (V − I = 2.03, ${R}_{{\rm{e}}}=0.28\,\mathrm{kpc}$ or 0.″48) that accounts for ≈81% of the total light in the I band. A circumgalactic ring of a diameter 16 kpc is also detected, with a disperse shape on its south side. The optical emission lines reveal the nucleus to be a broad-line LINER. Our MMT longslit observation indicates that the kinematics of the extended ${\rm{H}}\alpha $ emission is consistent with a rotational gaseous disk, with a mean blueshifted velocity of 162 $\mathrm{km}\,{{\rm{s}}}^{-1}$ and mean redshifted velocity of 86 $\mathrm{km}\,{{\rm{s}}}^{-1}$. According to our photoionization calculations, the large-scale ${\rm{H}}\alpha $ emission is unlikely to be powered by the central nucleus or by hot evolved (post-AGB) stars interspersed in the old stellar populations, but by in situ star formation, this is vindicated by the line-ratio diagnostic of the extended emission. We propose that both the ring and large-scale ${\rm{H}}\alpha $-emitting gas are created by the tidal accretion in a collision—and then merger—with a gas-rich galaxy of a comparable mass.

Following Greene & Ho (,: #apjaa5eb6bib31) and Dong et al. (, 2012: #apjaa5eb6bib21), hereinafter we refer to BHs with {M}_{\mathrm{BH}}\lt 2\times {10}^{6} {M}_{\odot } at the centers of galaxies as or BHs

accordingly, for the ease of narration wherever it is not ambiguous, hereinafter we refer to AGNs hosting low-mass BHs as low-mass AGNs or IMBH AGNs. Normally, we prefer to because of the possible confusion of the latter with the stellar-mass BHs in low-mass X-ray binaries (LMXBs)
According to (2016, private communication), AGN outflows, which can be launched even at very low accretion rates (e.g., Wang et al : #apjaa5eb6bib81

As cautioned they only identified ongoing mergers (and soon-to-be mergers) of two or more galaxies of comparable masses (see their Figure 4), and did not take into account any morphological features indicative of past major mergers or other violent interactions
we identify the companions only visually based on our HST images. We do not use well-defined criteria,...as this is not our main focus.
It was in the (candidate) sample of Greene & Ho (,: #apjaa5eb6bib31), i.e., not satisfying their quantitative detection threshold of broad {\rm{H}}\alpha but being picked up manually

J0838+5406 is picked up from the IMBH sample of (,: #apjaa5eb6bib21) that was based on the data set of the SDSS DR4. Here we use the spectral data reduced by the improved SDSS pipeline, version rerun 26, as released since the SDSS DR7, (downloadable at : instead of the data reductions archived in the SDSS DR4 (version rerun 23)
Interestingly, we first noticed this ring from the SDSS image, though the ring is faint and hard to discern there, and then we checked the HST archival data

They use 46 isolated stars in median-stacked form as an alternative PSF representation. The problem with this approach is the variety in the subpixel positioning of the stellar images, which leads to broadening in the PSF model when stacking a number of stars. In order to provide an accurate PSF model at all radii, they take the median-stacked star and replace the central pixels (within a radius of 3 pixels from the center) by the TinyTim model PSF. The flux values of these pixels are normalized such that the total flux of the newly constructed hybrid PSF model is the same as that of the stacked star. Their hybrid PSFs have a uniform pixel scale of 0\buildrel{\prime\prime}\over{.} 06

We use the program Gaia in the starlink software package : to fit a two-dimensional Gaussian to the source at the position of J0838+5406 in the VLA FIRST image. The source turns out to be point-like, with a flux of 0.84 mJy and an rms noise of 0.15 mJy. The source detection threshold set by the FIRST catalog is 1 mJy, so this source was not included in the official catalog. With a CLEAN bias (which always makes an underestimate of the flux) of 0.25 mJy : #apjaa5eb6bib5), the real flux of the source should be 1.09 mJy, 7.3 times the rms noise
The SDSS spectrum is extracted through a fiber aperture of 3'' in diameter, i.e., a radius (projected physical distance) of 0.9 kpc at this source's redshift

The parameter {\alpha }_{{\rm{H}}\alpha }^{\mathrm{eff}}({{\rm{H}}}^{0},T) is the effective recombination coefficient that reflects the number of recombinations to all n\geqslant 3 levels, which ultimately lead to transitions from n = 3 to n = 2 (namely emitting {\rm{H}}\alpha photons). The parameter {\alpha }_{B}({{\rm{H}}}^{0},T) is recombination coefficient. At {T}_{{\rm{e}}}={10}^{4} K and under the Case B condition (see Tables 2.1 and 4.2 of Osterbrock & Ferland,: #apjaa5eb6bib65), {\alpha }_{B}({{\rm{H}}}^{0},T) is 2.59\times {10}^{-13} cm3 s-1, {\alpha }_{{\rm{H}}\beta }^{\mathrm{eff}}({{\rm{H}}}^{0},T) is 3.03\times {10}^{-14} cm3 s-1, and the Balmer line-intensity ratio {j}_{{\rm{H}}\alpha }/{j}_{{\rm{H}}\beta }=2.87. According to \tfrac{{\alpha }_{{\rm{H}}\alpha }^{\mathrm{eff}}({{\rm{H}}}^{0},T)}{{\alpha }_{{\rm{H}}\beta }^{\mathrm{eff}}({{\rm{H}}}^{0},T)}=\tfrac{{j}_{{\rm{H}}\alpha }}{{j}_{{\rm{H}}\beta }}\tfrac{{\lambda }_{{\rm{H}}\alpha }}{{\lambda }_{{\rm{H}}\beta }} (see Equation (4.14) of Osterbrock & Ferland,: #apjaa5eb6bib65), {\alpha }_{{\rm{H}}\alpha }^{\mathrm{eff}}({{\rm{H}}}^{0},T) is 1.17\times {10}^{-13} cm3 s-1
